unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about understanding time zones in India. Right, buckle up, because it's less "Chai time at 4 PM" and more "Chai time... somewhere... possibly yesterday?".
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about understanding time zones in India. Right, buckle up, because it is less "Chai time at four P-M" and more "Chai time... somewhere... possibly yesterday?".

unnormalised: See, technically, India spans a fairly wide range of longitudes. That means different parts of the country *could* have their own local times. Imagine the chaos! Kolkata waking up hours before Mumbai. Banks opening at wildly different times! My poor brain trying to schedule a video call between Chennai and Guwahati! Instead, we bravely stick to one single, solitary time zone – Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. Bless.
normalised: See, technically, India spans a fairly wide range of longitudes. That means different parts of the country could have their own local times. Imagine the chaos! Kolkata waking up hours before Mumbai. Banks opening at wildly different times! My poor brain trying to schedule a video call between Chennai and Guwahati! Instead, we bravely stick to one single, solitary time zone – Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five hours and thirty minutes. Bless.

unnormalised: Now, this is where it gets a little… spicy. 5:30? Why not a nice, even 5 or 6? Well, blame the British, I guess (as we often do!). It’s related to the longitude of a town called Mirzapur, near Allahabad. So, we're perpetually half an hour out of sync with most of the world. It means when it's noon in London, it's 5:30 PM here. Try explaining *that* to your American cousin at 2 AM his time. Hilarity (and potential missed calls) ensues.

unnormalised: So, next time you're scheduling a meeting across India, remember: no need to factor in any weird regional time differences. Just remember that IST is always ready to be just that little bit awkward, eternally rocking the GMT+5:30 vibe. And maybe, just maybe, prepone that meeting so you can catch some sleep. You'll need it to deal with explaining this whole thing to anyone not born and raised in this glorious, time-zone-defying land.
